title: Jesus is moving‚ÄîPraise the LORD!
description:
Our friend, Yamil has been working as a contractor on our Building Team for a while now. Over his time with us, he‚Äôs become friends with many on staff and has been engaging in conversations about faith with our Building Manager, Ricky. Last week Ricky got to pray with Yamil as he accepted Jesus as Savior of his life. So we gathered some of the staff to celebrate as he put his lightbulb into the cross wall at our 515 location. Getting to celebrate people going from death to LIFE is something we will never get over. Each light bulb represents human hearts that have been changed by the Light of the World and are declaring that Jesus is Life. Let this be an encouragement that the environment you create and the way you treat each other matters. People are watching and we want others to see Jesus by the way we live.

title: Silent Nights ‚Äî Jeff Henderson
description:
What do you do when God is silent? Jeff Henderson reminds us that when God isn't speaking, it doesn't mean He isn't moving. When we look at the over 400 years of silence between Malachi and Matthew, we see how historical events during this stretch of time eventually led to aiding the spread of the Gospel, allowing us to trust that God is always active in our lives, even when we can't hear Him.

Louie Giglio takes this opportunity to remind listeners of the importance of bringing something to God that truly is sacrificial. God wants our worship and,  rather than being a people who give Him praise that costs us nothing, let us be a people who leave our gifts & time, goods & goals, highs & lows, and all our self-centeredness on the altar.

VERSES // Hebrews 10:14, Hebrews 13:11-16, Amos 5:21-24, Psalm 51:17, 2 Corinthians 5:14-15

title: The Seeing that Leads to Singing - Louie Giglio
description:
Continuing in the Collection of talks, ‚ÄúAll On The Altar,‚Äù Pastor Louie reminds listeners that there is a right way and a wrong way to respond to the miraculous work of God in our lives. Teaching from the text of Luke 17 and the story of the only grateful leper, Pastor Louie shows the crucial role that our 'sight' plays in worship.

VERSES // Luke 17:11-19, 1 Peter 2:9-10

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. What were the two initial components to Luke 17:11-13 that Pastor Louie mentioned? What is the significance of those components?
2. What was significant about the lepers being sent to the priest for clearance?
3. What was the significance of the inclusion of the fact that the leper was ‚ÄúA Samaritan‚Äù?
4. What was the difference for the one leper who returned to thank Jesus? What was the common-denominator for the nine who did not return?
5. What role does ‚Äúseeing God as He truly is‚Äù have in our worship?
6. How did salvation work before Jesus died on the cross? Try to explain this in your own words, if possible.
7. How could you carry a ‚ÄúGame-day‚Äù mentality into Sunday? What things could you do on Tuesday to prepare for church on Sunday?
8. How does Pastor Louie‚Äôs illustration about money help you think about generosity?
9. Pastor Louie read a list of ironies about God. Did any of these stand out to you? If so, why?
10. In your own words, try to answer this statement: ‚ÄúIt is rather selfish of God to be all about His own worship.‚Äù

title: Worship is a Verb - Louie Giglio
description:
Through numerous passages of Scripture, we see that "Worship" is a verb - an action-demanding response to the glory and grace of God. Pastor Louie shows listeners how worship calls us to kneel in submission, fear in reverence, sing with volume, and respond with entire-life submission to the only God deserving.

VERSES // Genesis 22:5, Psalm 96:1-13; 95:1-11, Psalm 33:1-3, John 4:19-24, Romans 12:1, Revelation 7:9-11

title: Hand It Over - Jonathan Pickens
description:
Jonathan Pickens delivers a powerful talk, pointing to three unique and unexpected examples from Scripture. There were three people (or groups) that "handed over" Jesus and His mission for the fleeting things of the world and we can learn from their mistake about the deception of our desires. Through Jesus, however, who handed Himself over for us, and by the power of the Spirit, we can walk faithfully without swerving from the truth.

VERSES // John 1, John 6:71, John 12:4-5, John 18:2, John 8:15, John 30-35, John 19:30, Matthew 26:14, Matthew 27:18

title: Fully Furnished, Fully Finished: Above + Beyond - Louie Giglio
description:
For this special Sunday gathering, Louie Giglio joins us to cast vision for how Above + Beyond allows us to give above what we normally give, to go beyond where we normally go. 
‚Äî
#faith #christian #sermon #passioncity #passioncityatlanta #atlanta #passioncitychurch #atlantachurch #christianity #Jesus #God

Follow Louie Giglio: https://www.instagram.com/louiegiglio 


Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.
‚Äî
DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //
1. When did you first hear about Passion City Church? What led you here? 
2. Unpack what Peterson shared about spending and income. He said, ‚ÄúFinancial challenge is typically a spending issue, not an income issue.‚Äù What did he mean by this?
3. How is money a ‚Äútool to be managed‚Äù rather than a lifeline to be loved? How would you explain this concept in your own words?
4. Philippians 3 contains a passage about the Apostle Paul‚Äôs view of abundance. How would you describe how ‚Äúgain‚Äù is ‚Äúloss‚Äù in light of Jesus?
5. Dukes reminds listeners that ‚ÄúLife doesn‚Äôt consist in the abundance of possessions‚Äù (Lk. 12:15). What are the things and experiences in life that lead us to forget this principle?
6. Dukes shares an amazing thought, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt control the economy but we can be good stewards of what God has entrusted to us.‚Äù What are some applications you can draw from this truth? What should we concern ourselves with and what should we not be anxious about?
7. Peterson shares that it is his family‚Äôs intention to ‚ÄúGive in such a way that we need God to provide.‚Äù What does this approach look like and how might it help you gauge what true generosity is for your life?
8. 2 Corinthians 8:2-5 is a powerful verse about the generosity of the early Church. Read it again together and answer this question: How did the churches of Macedonia give? What was their attitude?
9. Dukes shared that it is the hope of Passion City that, while everyone gives, everyone also receives. What are all the things we receive when we live generously?
10. Peterson closes the gathering by sharing this crucial truth: ‚ÄúGod is a giver, not a taker, and we - as His people - are to be imitators of Him.‚Äù Take a moment as a group to pray for direction around what God is calling you to invest on Above + Beyond Sunday.

8. How are discipleship and growth two sides of the same coin, when it comes to the activity of the Church?
9. In what ways is it possible to be involved in discipleship?
10. In what ways is it possible to be involved in the growth of the Church?

title: The Glorious View from the Above + Beyond - Louie Giglio
description:
Pastor Louie launches Passion City Church into the Above + Beyond season by pointing to Jesus, Who is the epitome of what it means to go ‚ÄúAbove + Beyond.‚Äù Jesus accomplished His self-sacrificing work to draw us to Him as worshipers and break us free from a ‚Äúsystem,‚Äù ‚Äúlie,‚Äù ‚Äúview,‚Äù and ‚Äúcity.‚Äù

VERSES // John 12:20-33, Hebrews 13:10-16, 2 Corinthians 5:21, Ephesians 2:4-10

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //
1. How would you describe what ‚ÄúAbove + Beyond‚Äù is to someone visiting Passion City Church?
2. Why is it important to be a giver not out of obligation but out of inclination?
In your own words, describe the balance we are called to maintain, between ‚Äúabusing grace‚Äù and being legalistic?
3. How is laying aside ‚Äòshame‚Äô up to us? What does it mean that Jesus already did His part in dealing with our shame?
4. What is your ‚Äúview of you‚Äù? In other words, if you are honest, what do you think about yourself in your best and worst moments?
5. Can you think of any passages in Scripture that specifically deal with the identity of people as followers of Jesus? In other words, what Scripture can we have on our minds to combat a ‚Äúlow view of self‚Äù?
6. What is the right attitude to have in enjoying the things of life that don‚Äôt last - things ‚Äúin this city‚Äù? 
7. In your own words, what should ‚ÄúThe Shard‚Äù remind us of?
8. Why is it that thinking about eternity helps us live generously?
9. Scripture calls us to ‚Äúpresent our requests to God‚Äù but it also calls us to seek God‚Äôs requests for ourselves (Eph. 5:17). Take a moment as a group to pray and ask God to speak to you during the Above + Beyond season.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //
1. What is on your Bucket List for life and your future adventures?
Was this how Paul actually felt? Is he using hyperbole (Rom. 1:8)?
2. Does an ‚Äúeagerness‚Äù to live on-mission mark your life?
3. According to Pastor Brad, what is it that breeds entitlement?
4. If you were to draft a mission statement for your life, what words would you want to incorporate?
5. Over the course of your life, what doors have opened? What doors closed?
6. Where has God placed you right now?
7. How has God uniquely gifted you?
8. What currently burdens you? Are you investing time into this area of interest?
9. Take a moment to speak into each other's lives. What opportunity do you see in the lives of the people around you?

title: How It Started / How It‚Äôs Going - Earl McClellan
description:
Pastor Earl McClellan dropped into Passion City to encourage listeners around the story of Paul and Silas‚Äô missionary journey to Philippi. McClellan speaks to all kinds of important truths, from the dynamic nature of God‚Äôs will and the importance of the ‚Äòmarketplace‚Äô in ministry to the authority given to us and the opportunity to witness in the midst of suffering.

VERSES // Acts 16:6-33

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. What‚Äôs a barrier or wall that showed up in your life that you later realized wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúbad‚Äù and from the Enemy but actually from God?
2. What is the significance of this ancient understanding; that ‚Äòdays‚Äô actually began at night?
3. What field or industry in your city can you think of that might be a part of God‚Äôs strategy to impact the world?
4. How do you discern if someone is saying the right things with the wrong intent? To what extent is it your responsibility to evaluate someone‚Äôs motive?
5. Why might God‚Äôs vision or dream for your life involve suffering? How can He still be loving if He allows pain? Try to answer in your own words.
6. Can you think of any other people like Paul and Silas from Scripture - people who have as many battle scars in their stories as they have victories?
7. What can we learn from Paul and Silas about how we should react in moments of suffering?
8. What is significant about the fact that the other prisoners were ‚Äúlistening‚Äù to Paul and Silas?
9. With all the craziness at Philippi, who was it that ended up receiving salvation? What made this possible?
10. Of all the things Pastor Earl touched on, what reminder do you want to ensure sticks with you?

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. What is your community timeline? In other words, how has your community been over the years? How is it now?
2. Would you describe yourself as an avoider of conflict or a head-on kind of person?
3. What was the point of Jesus‚Äô comment on forgiveness, according to Matthew 18:21-22?
4. What is the sin of the man in the parable about forgiveness and greed (Matt. 18:23-35)?
5. How much greater was the debt the king forgave this man than the debt he would not forgive his servant? How does this help you understand the grace of God?
6. What is the difference between ‚Äúbrushing something off‚Äù and offering Christlike grace to people?
7. What do expectations have to do with forgiveness?
8. How is the motivation of personal freedom not enough when it comes to the biblically-sound, genuine forgiveness God calls us to distribute?
9. What is it about forgiveness that leads people to think that it means they must neglect justice?
10. In your own words, how are forgiveness and justice two sides of the same coin?

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS
1. What is your history with your mom?

4. What qualities of your mom do you want to carry on and embrace?
5. What is Mother‚Äôs Day like for you? Is it joyous? Painful? A little of both?
6. If ‚ÄòCommunity‚Äô is a major piece of motherhood, what does that tell you about your mom, given the community she was surrounded by?
7. Read back through Matthew 14:22-33. What is something you saw in the text that you had never ‚Äúseen‚Äù before?
8. Watson shared about the importance of getting away to spend time reading Scripture and praying. When you do this, what is it like from beginning to end?
9. If you find yourself ‚Äúmaxed out‚Äù and without margin, what are the ‚ÄúVeggie Tales moments‚Äù of your day where God might speak to you through something unexpected?
10.Take a moment as you close to pray for a couple specific moms around your lives. Do you know any widows, moms struggling with infertility, moms who have run from God, or mothers who are worn out? Pray for them (they might be in your group).

9. What did the story of the North Korean woman lead you to think and feel?
10.As this collection of talks comes to a close, what reminders do you hope you carry with you through life?

title: What on Earth Are You Doing with Your Life? - Louie Giglio
description:
Pastor Louie challenges listeners by drawing attention to the 'dash' that represents our lives‚Äìthe tiny mark on gravestones that properly represents the 'mist' of a life we live. Ironically, however, it is the brevity of life that reminds us how precious it is to live and how crucial it is to live for Jesus. 

VERSES // 2 Peter 3:8-15, Psalm 90:10-12, Psalm 39:4-5, James 4:13-17, Luke 12:14-21

2. What are a few things or life experiences that make life feel long?
3. Have you ever been to a funeral/celebration of life? Were any especially memorable? For what reason?
4. How does the realization of the brevity of life help you live more like you are meant to live?
5. What‚Äôs the difference between saving wisely and ‚Äústoring up‚Äù excess? In other words, at what point does saving become unbiblical?
6. What does it mean to be ‚Äúfound spotless‚Äù if we are already saved and justified?
7. How does ‚Äúpeace with God‚Äù have to do with much more than being saved? If anything that is not aligned with His will is not at peace with Him, what part of your life is not as peace with God?
8. How do you think your life stacks up to the Apostle Paul or Peter‚Äôs life? What would you tell them if they asked you about your life‚Äôs ministry?
9. Pastor Louie mentioned that he did not want anyone to get legalistic with the call on our lives. What is the difference between living a life that counts out of obligation versus inclination?
10.This collection of talks has been a powerful reminder to live life on purpose. What can you do to remind yourself of the same truths and thinking that you have when leaving these talks?

title: Do Believers in Christ Face Judgment? - Louie Giglio
description:
Pastor Louie takes listeners further into a conversation about life and death by addressing the reality of the Great White Throne Judgment. The truth is that believers in Christ will face a post-salvation judgment of their works ‚Äì not for the sake of admittance into the Kingdom and the presence of God but for the sake of reward. Those who invest in what is earthly will see all their treasure burn up as waste but those who live faithfully, having invested their resources and time into the Kingdom, will reap an eternal reward.

VERSES // Revelation 20:11-15, 2 Corinthians 5:6-10, Hebrews 9:27, 1 Corinthians 2:10-15, 2 Corinthians 5:9-21, 2 Timothy 4:6-8

5. What does the Christian‚Äôs judgement look like? How are good works simultaneously not how we are saved but also how we will be judged?
6. How was Pastor Louie‚Äôs illustration about experiencing his father‚Äôs discipline ‚Äúwrong‚Äù (his words)?
7. If the Kingdom of Heaven has ‚Äúlevels‚Äù or ‚Äúclasses‚Äù to it, what kind of people will be in the ‚ÄúUpper Class‚Äù? Where do you anticipate you would reside if you died today? Would you be "Upper Class," "Lower Class," or somewhere in-between?
8. What of the investments in your life will be ‚Äúburned up‚Äù if you were to face the believer‚Äôs judgement today? Are all of the things that would be burned up ‚Äúbad‚Äù? Take time to answer this. What is the difference between living a wasteful life of materialism and living an investment-minded life, ‚Äúenjoying‚Äù things (1 Tim. 6:17)?
9. What injustice are you sitting in today, big or small, that will be made right at the Great White Throne judgement?
10. Explain in your own words how Christians are going to experience judgement and salvation simultaneously.

title: The Thief of Dreams Must Die | Louie Giglio | Passion City Church
description:
Pastor Louie talks to listeners about God-inspired dreams and visions and the ‚Äúthief‚Äù that comes to steal our dreams. In sharing about the life of Joseph, Pastor Louie points out that it is often through delay, betrayal, false accusation, being overlooked, jealousy, humiliation, exasperation, revenge, success, pain, separation, and comparison that the thief can successfully crush the dream God has for our life. However, it is faithfulness that kills the thief of dreams.

VERSES // Psalm 126, Genesis 37:11, Genesis 17-20, Genesis 41:14, Genesis 39-46, Genesis 50:15-20

Follow Louie Giglio: https://www.instagram.com/louiegiglio 


Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. What about Joseph‚Äôs story suggests that the realization of the dream God gives us may come in the ‚Äúdistance‚Äù?
2. What about Joseph‚Äôs dream seemed ‚Äúdreamy‚Äù? What about the reality was not dreamy?
3. What about the story of Joseph suggests that it is never too late to ‚Äúdream again‚Äù?
4. How was Joseph‚Äôs dream involving him but not about him?
5. Did Pastor Louie‚Äôs talk open your eye to any details you had previously not seen in the story of Joseph? What are those realizations?
6. Which element on the list of weapons that the thief uses caught your attention (Delay, Betrayal, etc.)? Which are being used on you today?
7. If faithfulness is what kills the thief of dreams, how do you gain faithfulness?
8. Do you have a dream for your life ‚Äì something that seems like a God-inspired, God-glorifying state of existence for your life? In other words, is there something you have always sought to do ‚Äì or be enabled to do - for the glory of God?
9. What is standing in the way of the dream you have for your life? If you are already living in the dream God has for your life, what were the unexpected things that preceded it?
10.If you feel stuck and you are unsure as to what God might be dreaming and envisioning for your life, allow the group to encourage you with what they see as a possibility for your life. Practically speaking, this looks like telling the people in the group where you see them being most impactful and God-glorifying with their story, gifts, and circumstances.

title: Out of the Ashes to Dream Again - Louie Giglio
description:
Inspired by Passion‚Äôs recent trip to the Holy Land, Pastor Louie shares a powerful talk on the "road" to revitalized dreams. The excavation of the ‚ÄúPilgrim Road‚Äù drove Pastor Louie to share on the importance of God‚Äôs timing and His will to draw us into His presence. Under the ruin, the layers of dirt and decay lie a path toward freedom and a relationship with God. It is on this path and in His presence that we regain our ability to dream; to envision our unique life lived for the glory of God and the good of others.

VERSES // Psalm 126, Acts 2:14-21, Isaiah 60:22, Joel 2:28-32

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. What was Pastor Louie‚Äôs story of the family at the airport all about? What is the spiritual reality behind this image?
2. What is the ‚Äòdream‚Äô Pastor Louie talks about? Where does this ‚Äòdream‚Äô originate?
3. Can you put words to the dream God has put on your heart and life?
4. What is the significance of the ‚Äústreams in the Negev‚Äù (Ps. 126:5-6)? What irony can be found in this?
5. Try to recall what was the purpose of the ‚ÄúSouthern Steps.‚Äù How could the concept of the ‚ÄòAscent‚Äô be replicated today when it comes to meeting with God publicly and privately?
6. What is powerful about archaeological excavation? Pastor Louie alludes to the importance of ‚Äúgiving God time.‚Äù What is his point in sharing this?
7. Does anyone know of any other faith-affirming archaeological excavations?
8. Read Psalm 126:5-6. When was the last time you cried and what was it that led you to cry?
9. Has God ever used the sowing of your tears to reap a harvest? Share that story with your group.
10.What is the ‚Äòstep‚Äô God may be calling you to take right now ‚Äì to make progress on the pilgrim‚Äôs road?

title: The Unexpected Adventure - Lee Strobel
description:
Lee Strobel has been directing skeptics to the investigation of the person of Jesus since The Case For Christ came off the press in 1998. In this talk, Strobel urges listeners to live their lives on the "evangelistic edge" by asking the question, ‚ÄúWhat would it look like if Jesus lived under your roof?‚Äù 

VERSES // Matthew 5:12-16, James 5:18, 1 Peter 3:15

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. Have you ever read The Case For Christ? Do you remember some of the evidences ‚Äì whether from Strobel‚Äôs book or elsewhere - for the resurrection of Jesus?
2. What resources do you know of (scholars, books, talks, podcasts, etc.) that deal with the topic of apologetics? Are there any you know you can direct people to if they want to learn?
3. What can we learn from the life and thinking of John the Baptist when it comes to the topic of Skepticism?
4. Why is it that Strobel calls prayer ‚Äúthe best place to start‚Äù in evangelism?
5. Let‚Äôs answer Strobel‚Äôs question. If Jesus met you and answered every prayer you prayed in the past week, what prayers would be answered?
6. Who is the person you have ceased praying for or wavered in praying for? Try to name the person who has often slipped your mind.
7. Aside from the three points Strobel made, how would Jesus conduct Himself if He lived among us today? How would He act at the grocery store? How would He act at the gym? How would He act at church on Sunday?
8. What are a couple questions you have about the faith, theology, Scripture, or Apologetics, that you have not sought answers for? What could you begin to investigate? Starting your investigation by presenting that question to the group.
9. What is the concept behind ‚ÄòRicochet Evangelism‚Äô? Do you have any similar stories like the one Strobel shared?
10.Who are the people that came to your mind during Strobel‚Äôs talk? Share those names and plan to keep the group updated on the opportunities God gives you to point them to Jesus.

title: The Best Thing to Do with Your Anxiety - Louie Giglio
description:
To close out a powerful collection of talks on the enemy and the weight of anxiety, Pastor Louie leads listeners in a response; to declare Jesus over our circumstances and join in prayer with those who are in the pit of their struggle with anxiety. He shares four crucial words to respond as followers of Jesus to the pressure that comes with our anxious thoughts: Humble, Cast, Lift, and Care. By walking through the process embedded in these words and in this Scripture, we respond as God intended us to respond to fear, depression, and anxiety.

VERSES // 1 Peter 5:6-7

#faith #christian #sermon #passioncity #passioncityatlanta #atlanta #passioncitychurch #atlantachurch #christianity #Jesus #God
‚Äî
With Passion City Online, you can join us every Sunday live at 9:30a and 11:45a, and our gatherings are available on-demand starting at 7p! Join us at https://passioncitychurch.com
‚Äî
Subscribe to our channel to see more messages from Passion City Church: 
https://www.youtube.com/passioncitychurch1
‚Äî

https://passion.link/passionkidsonline

‚Äî

‚Äî

‚Äî
Follow Passion City Church: https://www.instagram.com/passioncity/ 
Follow Louie Giglio: https://www.instagram.com/louiegiglio 


Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //
1. What does society point toward to relieve stress and anxiety? Take a quick second to pull out your phones and research what the experts of the day are suggesting.
2. Of all that is recommended on the internet, what advice can you parallel with the Word of God? In other words, are there any passages in Scripture that suggest something similar to what psychologists and therapists are suggesting?
3. How do you ‚ÄúHumble yourself‚Äù? What practical things can you do to contribute to making yourself a humble person before God?
4. As a group, try to name 10 experiences that are humbling in nature. To help think of things, try to answer this question ten times: ‚ÄúWhat is something that makes you feel small, life feel short, or God seem great?‚Äù
5. If anxiety were a physical object, it would be simple to ‚Äúcast‚Äù it but what does it mean to ‚Äúcast‚Äù something nonphysical, like anxiety?
6. What are practical things you can do to cast anxiety on God (Hint: 1 Pet. 5:1-5; 8-11)? If something you think of seems obvious, still share it with the group because it may be informative to someone else.
7. Pastor Louie asked the people of our House to raise their hands if they ever had a moment in their life where they ‚Äúfelt like they were actually going crazy.‚Äù If you had that moment in your life and you feel comfortable, share as much of the context around that time as you would like to share.
8. Many people struggle to relate to people facing anxiety and depression. If this is you, and you cannot name a time where you dealt with all that intense an anxiety, what are some of the practices in your life that may contribute to your having a relatively ‚Äúsound‚Äù mind?
9. If you think you are ‚Äúsound‚Äù in mind, what is your plan to stay ‚Äúwatchful‚Äù (1 Pet. 5:8)?
10.What anxieties are you dealing with currently? If you feel comfortable to share, bring them to the group so someone in the group can pray over your situation. End by praying for each other.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. How do you answer the question, ‚ÄúTo what extent do you rely on a doctor when it comes to the need for healing?‚Äù? 
2. Pastor Louie shared about the issue of ‚ÄúText Neck.‚Äù Do any of you know any practical exercises or keys to preventing this bad habit? 
3. What are your thoughts on the article, ‚ÄúThe Surprising Joy of Raising Your Gaze‚Äù? Were you surprised to hear about these results? 
4. What might physiological and psychological discoveries like these suggest about our faith and the instruction in Scripture? 
5. This may be strange to do as a group ‚Äì and you will need to do this when it‚Äôs dark outside - so feel free to skip this step. Take 10 minutes of group time to get up, go outside, ‚Äúlook up‚Äù and find the Big Dipper, Little Dipper, and NorthStar.
6. Let‚Äôs talk about the process toward lifting our gaze. What will you think of when you choose to ‚Äúremember the narrative we are in‚Äù? 
Pastor Louie mentioned listening to ‚ÄúSpeak Jesus‚Äù about 1,000 times during a difficult season. 7. Do you have a season like this? Do you have a song of praise you played through it? 
8. What does it mean to ‚Äúexercise your right to hope in God‚Äù? 
9. Where does your ‚Äúhelp come from‚Äù in times of need? The biblical answer is ‚ÄúThe LORD‚Äù but try to unpack just how ‚Äúthe LORD‚Äù helps you (Ps. 121:1). For instance, did He use a doctor or therapist? 

**If your group has reached a place of transparency, ask this final question.

10. Where has ‚Äúhelp come from‚Äù that was not a healthy source? In other words, who/what have you turned to for help‚Äîin the past or recently‚Äîthat you should not have turned to?

description:
Breathing Out the Weight of Depression - Louie Giglio - https://youtu.be/AYwRqX6kSV0

Pastor Louie leads our House into a new Collection of Talks, titled, ‚ÄòPutting an ‚ÄòX‚Äô Through Anxiety‚Äô.  In this talk, Pastor Louie urges listeners to get back in touch with the breath of God‚ÄîHis Spirit. It is breathing IN the truth about God and the actual physical breath that He gives us that ultimately combats the anxiety and depression that ravage our nation. It is in breathing OUT worship and truth that ultimately leads to an offensive attack on the schemes of the Enemy. 

VERSES // Ezekiel 37:1-14, Genesis 1:2, Genesis 2:7, Acts 17:25, Romans 8:9

6. What role does ‚Äòisolation‚Äô play in increasing anxiety?
7. What role does ‚Äòself-focus‚Äô play in increasing anxiety?
8. What role does ‚Äògratitude‚Äô play in combatting anxiety?

10. If your group is already to a place of transparency, take a moment now and pray for anyone who is in the midst of a storm of anxiety or depression.

1. Pastor Louie began his talk by mentioning the culture in 1st Century Greece. He said something about how the people of the day valued spirit but not body. Retell this fact and its cultural implications. Can you remember this from history class?
2. How is the first implication both good AND bad news?
3. What does it mean to ‚Äústop trying‚Äù to be good enough for God? What changes when we go from trying to not trying, our actions? Motives? Beliefs?
4. How is the Gospel something a person ‚Äústands on‚Äù? What does it typically take for someone to go from seeing the Gospel as something you make a decision about once to being something you ‚Äústand on‚Äù?
5. How do you answer the question, ‚ÄúHow do you know that you are saved?‚Äù?
6. What do verses 10+11 mean? What is the purpose of ‚Äògrace‚Äô after getting saved? This may be tricky so be encouraged to wrestle with this together.
7. Why does the Gospel ‚Äúrelease you from the grip of religion‚Äù?
8. What popular thinking habits do we let go of because of our priorities?
9. Who are the lost people you are praying for? How can you take a step toward sharing with them?
10.Pastor Louie says there are 100 ways to pass on the message of the Gospel. What ways have you ‚Äúpassed on the message‚Äù before?

description:

‚Äî
Pastor Grant Partrick shares a convicting talk about distraction and its role in the theft of the devotion God deserves. He challenges listeners through the story of Martha‚Äôs busyness to bring awareness to the pressing and increasing need for attentiveness. 

Pastor Grant highlights three major truths to lead us to ask the question, ‚Äúare there any things you need to stop doing, start doing, or do differently?‚Äù:

1. Distraction is the great enemy of devotion.
2. Busyness is never the goal.
3. Our distractions move toward devotion through a vehicle called ‚ÄòDiscipline‚Äô.

Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS //

1. Pastor Grant started the talk off with a story about hospitality. How is your hospitality this year? What are some hospitality aspirations/dreams/goals you have for your life?
2. Read back through Luke 10:38-43. Pause for a moment and have someone in the group pray that God will use this text to continue to impact the lives of the people in your group.
3. What all does it mean and represent to be ‚Äúat the feet of Jesus‚Äù?
4. What was at the root of Martha‚Äôs mistake?
5. Do you have a story from a time where you were distracted from what is best by something that is good?
6. Pastor Grant shared about the Mood that is being used in the original Greek verb, ‚Äúto do.‚Äù He went on to suggest that we should never use the ‚Äòimperative‚Äô Mood when speaking to God. What is the ‚ÄúImperative Mood‚Äù and why should we not use it with God? When might be a time where it would be acceptable to use this Mood in speaking to God?
7. Why did Jesus use Martha‚Äôs name twice? What was likely the meaning in this repetition?
8. Pastor Grant asked a convicting question that requires a little more transparency than normal. Let‚Äôs answer it together: ‚ÄúIs there anything in you that is distracting you from what matters most?‚Äù
9. When does serving and working for Jesus lose its meaning? In other words, at what point does it become distracting?
10.Pastor Grant urged our House to ask and answer this question: ‚ÄúWhat are you most committed to in life?‚Äù Did you write anything down or can you answer if there is something from your daily schedule you need to ‚Äústart doing,‚Äù ‚Äústop doing,‚Äù or ‚Äústart doing differently‚Äù?

title: Faith/Wisdom #shorts #christian #christianity #jesus #god
description:
Dr. Coe joined this collection of talks with a strong word about the intersection between faith and wisdom ‚Äì the space we are designed to occupy. It is in this intersection that we properly live our lives as God intended them to be lived, leveraging our gifting and glorifying His name. 

VERSES // Psalm 90:17, Jeremiah 29:11, Luke 14:38, Psalm 90:12

Follow Louie Giglio: https://www.instagram.com/louiegiglio 


Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS // 

1. Have you ever been a part of the house-building process, whether overseeing the work as the eventual owner or an active participant in the construction process? What was your experience?
2. Are you a planner or do you resonate with the ‚Äúready, aim, fire,‚Äù motto for life?
3. What kind of season are you currently in, a descent, valley, or ascent?
4. Can you think of any instances in Scripture where people do ‚Äòplanning,‚Äô whether God or His people?
5. What is a a story from a time when your ‚Äòreality‚Äô was far from your ‚Äòplan‚Äô?
6. What role does wisdom play in the process of planning well?
7. One of the ways we determine our giftings is by hearing from the people who notice them in our lives. What are your gifts? If anyone can identify any giftings in the room, please share those as well.
8. Repeat what Dr. Coe shared about Paul ‚Äúnot going to Asia‚Äù and ‚Äúbeing a witness to the ends of the earth‚Ä¶in Atlanta.‚Äù What is the idea behind this?
9. What does ‚Äúnumber our days‚Äù mean? What does it not mean?
10.In your own words, what is the purpose of the questions Dr. Coe urged us to ask ourselves? Which of the four were most convicting and why?

4. What are your gifts and how do you intend to use them this year? In what ways will they contribute to your requirements and desires?
5. Have you ever experienced the overlap of these three areas of your life? What was that like?
6. What are your primary concerns this month? What continues to come up, interrupting your sleep, work, and life?
7. What did you learn from Ephesians 2, Colossians 3 and your ‚Äúcurrent spiritual position‚Äù? Is this difficult to wrap your mind around? If so, why?
8. What for you is getting in that ‚Äúmiddle space‚Äù ‚Äì where all three of these categories (requirements, desires, and purpose) overlap?
9. How do you ‚Äúfind your Father‚Äù? Do you ‚Äúfind Him‚Äù before everything else you find in the day? How do you start your typical morning?
10.When was the last time you asked God in the mundane to use you supernaturally? Take a moment now to ask God to remind you in the ‚Äúnatural‚Äù moments to think, pray, and ask for the supernatural.

description:

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS:
1. What is the difference in heart, between asking God to bless your plans and asking God what His plans are for your life?
2. What worldly needs make you anxious?
3. Which needs get in the way of your spiritual needs?
4. Where are the ‚Äúfields‚Äù in your life that are ‚Äúripe for harvest‚Äù?
5. What is the difference between believing in Jesus because of obligation and believing in Jesus because of inclination?
6. When did your faith become personal? What led to this crucial switch?
7. If this year is going to be marked by evangelism and winsomeness - for you specifically - what will you be doing differently?
8. What truths about ministry and evangelism can you draw from the story of the Woman at the Well?
9. What is not true about ministry and evangelism, according to the story of the Woman at the Well?
10.Take a moment and pray for opportunities to point people to Jesus this year.

title: When Grace Comes to Town - Brad Jones
description:
Pastor Brad Jones took our House into our final talk before Christmas Eve by highlighting the theological significance of Jesus‚Äô arrival: When Jesus came, grace came. This reality was of massive significance to a people steeped in religiosity. As people who have received grace, we are now to grow in grace - toward others and ourselves.

VERSES // John 1:14, John 1:1-5, John 1:18, John 1:36-42, 2 Peter 3:18

DISCUSSION QUESTIONS
1. Who is the most famous person to come to your hometown? If you are from a big town, who is the most famous person you have run into in public?
2. Why was it a big deal for grace to come? What was the religious context behind Jesus‚Äô birth?
3. Pastor Brad briefly shared the answer to this important question: What is the best way to tell what God is like?
4. What is God‚Äôs posture toward us, according to Pastor Brad? How is this different from how other faiths portray their gods?
5. What was your upbringing like when it comes to the subject of grace? Was your household full of grace or was it a graceless place?
6. In your own words, what does it mean to ‚Äúgrow in grace‚Äù?
7. When Paul sought to have the ‚Äúthorn‚Äù in his flesh removed, Scripture reveals that it was ‚Äògrace‚Äô that Paul needed. Why was it that sufficient grace was what Paul needed in his struggle?
8. Pastor Brad urges our House to be a people who point others toward grace. If you were to evaluate your character, would you say you tend to lean more toward being a gracious person or a graceless person? How
so?
9. If your eagerness to point people to Jesus is a good indicator of your humility and your heart‚Äôs purity, then what does your current outlook say about your heart?
10. How would you describe your current role in the Kingdom of God? Do you ever envy another role ‚Äì someone at work? At church?

title: The whole world is a target of the birth of Jesus Christ. #shorts #jesus #faith
description:
In this advent message, Pastor Louie emphasizes a few major components of the story of Jesus' birth; that the story‚Äîthat Jesus is King‚Äîhas global significance, it is staunchly opposed by the darkness, and it ends with every knee bowing to King Jesus. Let the "Wise" people seek Him today, family, because He is who He says He is.

VERSES // Matthew 2:1-11, Matthew 1:16-17, Acts 2:22-24, Philippians 2:6-11, Revelation 11:15-19

Discussion Questions
1. Pastor Louie emphasizes the fact that the story of Jesus is a global story. What are some of the reasons why it is helpful to our faith to know that this message is for the whole world and trusted by many?
2. What stories have you heard recently about churches and followers of Jesus in other nations and countries?
3. Last week, we answered the question, "why did Jesus come when He came?" Can anyone recall the supposed answer to this question?
4. Pastor Louie shares about King Herod and his opposition. What do you know about the "intense opposition of the darkness" in the world today? Do you know of anyone being persecuted?
5. Think about the different religions of the world and what they say about the person of Jesus. What is the consensus across the globe about who Jesus is? What do we claim, as followers of Jesus?
6. What is 'wisdom,' in your own words?
7. What is the connection between 'wisdom' and the "fear of the Lord?"
8. This may not be a simple answer but can people possess wisdom without "fearing God"?
9. What did the map you saw and the effort to which wise men went help you realize?
10. Who do you want your group to hold you accountable for‚Äìsomeone you want to invite to Christmas Eve?

title: Blessed and Highly Favored - Louie Giglio
description:
Pastor Louie leads our House into the Advent season by highlighting the miraculous birth of Jesus, through Mary, the ‚Äúblessed and highly favored‚Äù mother of Jesus and instrument for God‚Äôs grace-filled work. Pastor Louie directs followers of Jesus to sit long enough under the ‚Äúflow‚Äù of God‚Äôs grace to be moved to worship and reciprocate the same great blessing.

VERSES // Luke 1:26-80

Discussion Questions //

1. Pastor Louie reminds us that we are all in ‚Äúwaiting periods,‚Äù as a result of the way God works to build our faith. What was the longest ‚Äúwaiting period‚Äù you have experienced?
2. What was Mary‚Äôs response to the angel Gabriel compared to Zechariah‚Äôs response? You may have to read back through the stories to compare the two figures.
3. Why did the baby (John the Baptist) leap in the womb? There is not a clear answer in Scripture but that does not mean we cannot postulate!
4. What is the context behind Mary‚Äôs comments about ‚ÄòAbraham‚Äô? Can anyone explain Mary‚Äôs thinking?
5. Pastor Louie says Mary, the mother of Jesus, ‚Äúchose the side of faith‚Äù in speaking about her response to the angel Gabriel. What does it mean to ‚Äúchoose the side of faith‚Äù? What did it mean for Mary?
6. What are you currently waiting for in life?
7. How might God be using what you are currently ‚Äúwaiting for‚Äù to grow your faith?
8. What did you learn from Mary‚Äôs life as she serves as an example for followers of Jesus today?
9. Pastor Louie says that an emphasis on God‚Äôs grace results in worship. Why does an emphasis on and awareness of grace and mercy lead to worship?
10. If appreciation for God‚Äôs  grace  leads us to worship, then how do you increase your appreciation for grace? Is there anyone that found something helpful or eye-opening in regard to this appreciation?

Discussion Questions //

9. How do you ‚ÄúAgree with God‚Äù? What stands in the way of ‚ÄúAgreement‚Äù?
10. Which of the different applications were most impactful and why?

title: How can we shift our prayers? #shorts #god #christian
description:
In our current collection of talks titled, ‚ÄòSHIFT,‚Äô Pastor Louie challenges the idea that so many people hold: ‚ÄúMy prayers don‚Äôt work.‚Äù He responds to this thought by directing our House to try realigning our will with the will of God, praying through Scripture, knowing it is God‚Äôs will on a tangible page, and praying bold, offensive prayers.

VERSES // 1 John 4:14-15; Acts 1:8; 4:20-28; Ephesians 4:32; 1 Thessalonians 5:17; Revelation 21:4

#faith #christian #sermon #passioncity #passioncityatlanta #atlanta #passioncitychurch #atlantachurch #christianity #Jesus #God
‚Äî
With Passion City Online, you can join us every Sunday live at 9:30a and 11:45a, and our gatherings are available on-demand starting at 7p! Join us at https://passioncitychurch.com
‚Äî
Subscribe to our channel to see more messages from Passion City Church: 
https://www.youtube.com/passioncitychurch1
‚Äî
Looking for content for your Kids? Subscribe to our Passion Kids Channel:
https://passion.link/passionkidsonline 
‚Äî
If you would like to give to our house, visit https://passioncitychurch.com/give/
‚Äî
Check out Passion's books, music, and more at https://passionresources.com/
‚Äî
At Passion City Church, we believe that because God has displayed the ultimate sacrifice in Jesus, our response to that in worship must be extravagant. It is our privilege, and our created purpose, to reflect God‚Äôs Glory to Him through our praise, our sacrifice, and our song. 
‚Äî
Follow Passion City Church: https://www.instagram.com/passioncity/ 
Follow Louie Giglio: https://www.instagram.com/louiegiglio 


Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.

Discussion Questions //

1. Why do bold prayers begin with ‚Äòalignment‚Äô? Try to reexplain this in your own words.
2. What is the ‚Äòwill‚Äô of God, according to 1 John 4?
3. Why does Pastor Louie say that it is amazing that we can come to the throne of God ‚Äúand not die‚Äù? What is the historical, theological context around this statement?
4. How have your desires shifted over time? Early on in following Jesus, were you aligned with God? What were your desires before you started following Jesus?
5. Pastor Louie shares, ‚ÄúIf you get into His Word, you figure out what His will is.‚Äù What have you learned is a component of God‚Äôs will for your life and the world, according to His Word?
6. Pastor Louie recommends a great idea in ‚Äúpraying through Scripture.‚Äù Take a moment as a group and turn to a passage of Scripture and pray through the text. If you cannot think of a text to pray through, turn to Ephesians 1:15-23 and take turns praying short, Scripture-informed prayers.
7. Pastor Louie shares a powerful story about God‚Äôs supernatural work on a dark college campus. What does the thought ‚Äì that God can do immeasurably more than we can imagine through our prayers ‚Äì challenge you to try?
8. Who are the people you are burdened for, currently? Share this with the group so that you can be held somewhat accountable to be praying for them.

title: You have an opportunity to call on HEAVEN. #shorts #christian #christianity
description:
Continuing in our current collection of talks, Shift, Pastor Louie challenges how we come before God in prayer. As he breaks down the many requests we put before God out of habit and religion, he instead encourages us to pray out of a desire to have a close relationship with the creator of the universe.

VERSES // Matthew 5:4,6:5-8,10, Ephesians 1:3, Genesis 49:22-26, Galatians 2:20, Acts 4:29-30, Colossians 2:13-14

 7. What is the main idea, in your own words, behind this past Sunday‚Äôs message? 8. What does it look like to pray simply?
 9. What is your reaction to having these routine prayers challenged?

Discussion Questions //
1. What stands out from Pastor Louie‚Äôs definition of ‚ÄòPrayer‚Äô? Are there any pieces to that definition that are surprising or new to you?
2. What was or is your relationship with your earthly father like?
3. How might your relationship with your earthly father affect the way you perceive and understand relationship with a heavenly Father?
4. It is so easy to read the famous, ‚ÄúLord‚Äôs Prayer‚Äù and ignore the substantial, exemplary truths present in it. Read this passage together and answer the following question (Matt. 6:9-13). Which words or phrases did you view differently after hearing this talk from Pastor Louie?
5. The Lord‚Äôs Prayer begins with adoration of God. What are some things that have genuinely amazed you about our God, recently? What is something from creation that has left you in awe of the Creator?
6. Pastor Louie mentions the ‚Äòmajesty‚Äô of the Queen of England. How does picturing earthly royalty help you think through how we should view our Almighty God?
7. What does it look like to switch ‚Äúhuman-wishes‚Äù for ‚ÄúGod-wishes‚Äù? How is prayer a way to seal your desire to exchange these wishes for each other?
8. Are ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs wishes‚Äù different from your wishes? How are they similar and how are the different?
9. What stands in the way of you being a more prayerful person? What are some practices you can recommend to each other? For instance, ‚Äúinstead of texting someone, ‚ÄúI will be praying for you!‚Äù send those words AND include a prayer in that very text.

title: Becoming an Influencer - Brad Jones
description:
Pastor Brad closes out our ‚ÄòOpen House‚Äô collection of talks by urging us to live our lives set apart and as a response to the goodness of God toward us. His talk reminds us that our lives‚Äîthough seemingly ordinary‚Äîcan be available and used to impact the world, by the grace of God.

Becoming an Influencer - Brad Jones

VERSES // Romans 1:16-17,12:1-21

Discussion Questions //

Pastor Brad begins the talk by sharing about the potential we hold as ‚Äúordinary" people. What "ordinary‚Äù person have you seen do something incredibly impactful?

Pastor Brad says 'pride‚Äô is the greatest threat to our church. What does he mean by this?

Where are you most prideful? In other words, when do you feel the need to exalt your own reputation?

If you can identify instances where you are prideful, can you identify the source of your pride? What is the reason or the insecurity behind your prideful action?

Maybe you are having a hard time seeing your actions as prideful. How about starting with this question: When was the last time you subtly bragged or quietly boasted in something about yourself?

Pastor Brad urges our House to live humbly because humility is attractive to others and it leads to influence. How do you practice humility?
P
astor Brad shares, ‚ÄúHonor is INexpensive‚Äù and ‚ÄúJealousy is expensive.‚Äù What does he mean by this?

Pastor Brad encourages our House to be hope-filled people because it stands out to others. Living with hope is one of the most difficult things we do because it is always paired with hardship. When was the last time you had to focus intently on the hope we have as followers of Jesus? 

What were you facing in that valley of life?

What stands out from Pastor Brads talk? What did you need to be reminded of?

Reread the Scripture Pastor Brad references. What did you need to be reminded of in these texts?

title: What God Does When We Let Go - Louie Giglio
description:
This past Sunday, Pastor Louie was back with a message about the return that comes with kingdom investment. When we sow into the Kingdom of heaven, we invest in an initiative that reaps unquantifiable return. As we were able to bless numerous organizations through Above + Beyond, He reminds us that our gifts are now launched into the atmosphere and used for kingdom purposes.

What God Does When We Let Go - Louie Giglio

VERSES // Matthew 5:14-16,16:24-25, Exodus 2:1-10

Discussion Questions //
1. Pastor Louie talked about MECO, a term astronauts use. What was the idea behind this analogy?
2. In Matthew 16:24-27 Jesus talks about the danger of ‚Äúgaining the world.‚Äù What does it look like in our day and age to ‚Äúgain the world‚Äù? Is it wrong to ‚Äúgain the world‚Äù? Why or why not?
3. Pastor Louie pointed out the biblical reality; that when we ‚Äúrelease,‚Äù miracles, deliverance, provision, and salvation happens. To what extent are these things guaranteed in this life, when we ‚Äúrelease‚Äù? To what extent are they going to be rewarded in heaven? Talk about this answer with humility, because there is a great deal of mystery in thinking about God‚Äôs sovereignty.
4. What should be our expectation when we give from the resources God has entrusted to us?
5. What should be our response when we give but do not get?
6. What was your reaction to seeing the videos of these organizations receiving your gifts? Explain what you felt, desired, were encouraged by, and imagined.
7. Pastor Louie shared the example of Jochebed. What caught your attention or was new about this story? For instance, had you ever thought much about Jochebed?
8. One of the calls Pastor Louie gave to our House was to consider further involvement in the organizations we support (Operation Mobilization, Friends of Refugess, etc.). Have any of you ever served with any of these organizations or a similar organization? Share your experience!
9. Pastor Louie read Jesus‚Äô words; that you should ‚Äústore up for yourselves treasures in heaven (Matt. 5:16).‚Äù What do you think heavenly treasure consists of?

title: Salt + Light - Grant Patrick
description:
Pastor Grant brought our House back from Sabbath by introducing a new collection of talks, ‚ÄòOpen House.‚Äô Sharing from Matthew 5:13-16, Grant reiterates that we are here to be a preservative to the goodness that was modeled by Jesus and reflectors of the marvelous light of God. So, we seek reconciliation, not retaliation. We resist greed through generosity. And finally, we submit to authority rather than rebelling against it.

Salt + Light - Grant Patrick

VERSES // Matthew 5:13-16,5:44-48, Genesis 1:3, James 1:17, John 8:12,9:5, 2 Corinthians 4:6, 1 Peter 2:9,3:5, Ephesians 5:8, Hebrews 10:24-25

Discussion Questions //
1. What comes to mind when you hear that there is a call to be generous ‚Äúwith your life‚Äù?
2. What was Jesus‚Äô purpose in sharing a metaphor about salt? What does it mean to be ‚Äòsalt‚Äô of the earth?
3. Why did Jesus share the metaphor about light? What does it mean to be ‚Äòlight‚Äô in the world?
4. Do you have a person from your past that comes to mind in thinking about what it looks like to embody these metaphors?
5. What do you sense or know is your contribution in conversations? Are you known as a negative person? What is your tendency?
6. How is it simultaneously true that Jesus is the light of the world and we ‚Äì the Church ‚Äì are the light of the world?
7. Pastor Grant urged us to be people who live as reconcilers. What does this look like and what about reconciliation makes it one of the most difficult things a Christian is called to do?
8. What does it look like, practically, to ‚Äúhide a lamp under a basket‚Äù?
9. Pastor Grant shared about the Greek word for ‚Äòlight‚Äô ‚Äì ‚ÄòPhotos‚Äô. What was his analogy about in comparing himself with his dad?
10. Pastor Grant shared about doing things that make you ‚Äòbrighter.‚Äô What is something you need to do to live more brightly?
11. Is there a person in your life with whom you want to reconcile things? This may be a really difficult step but if you feel the conviction, it might be worth sharing it with the group.
12. What are the character traits of the people of God, according to Matthew 5?

title: Sabbath: Stop, Rest, and Remember
description:
AUGUST 27-SEPTEMBER 3, 2023

Pastor Brad and Pastor Grant join us as they come around the meaning of Sabbath and why our House is committing to rest. As we observe the Sabbath this year, we are taking these two Sundays to stop, rest, and remember what God has done. We realize the idea of NOT MEETING is a little crazy on the surface, but we are guided by a deeper spiritual belief that God intended to weave Sabbath rest into the fabric of creation. We believe that as we cease from our efforts and celebrate again that God is the source of all we have and need, we will experience renewed strength and vision as a House.

To find out more about Sabbath at Passion City Church, visit https://passioncitychurch.com/sabbath/.

title: ABOVE + BEYOND - Generations
description:
Launching into Above + Beyond Sunday, we're reminded of the legacy that we each leave behind for generations to come. Looking back to Apollo 11, we see how the first flight in 1903 paved the way for Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong to leave their footprints on the moon. Fast forward a few years, and we are met with the personal story of the Nobles family‚Äîthe faith of a woman in our House leading to the faith of her daughter-in-law, leading to her grandkids being raised in a home filled with faith. Faith leaves a legacy.

title: Into the Above and Beyond - Louie Giglio
description:
This is Above + Beyond Sunday‚Äìa day where our House gives above our normal giving so that we can go beyond where we normally go. In this talk from Pastor Louie, the invitation‚Äìto step into the investment that reaps an exponential return‚Äìis extended. This is invitation is about more than what is monetary. It is about surrendering to Jesus and placing our everything in His hands.

VERSES // Romans 7:21-25,8:1-2, Colossians 3:1-4, Mark 12:42-44

Discussion Questions //
1. What stood out from the Nobles‚Äô story? Do you relate with any of the components in Sarah, Bryson, Janelle, or Michael‚Äôs testimony?
2. Pastor Louie taught, ‚ÄúWe are working to overcome something greater, another law, the law of sin and death‚Äù in highlighting the Law of Gravity. Read Romans 7 together and discuss this idea. What is the "law of sin and death" in your own words?
3. What excites you about the future of the Church? What excites you about the future of Passion City Church?
4. Which of the Partners mentioned in the talk interest you and why (God Behind Bars, Operation Mobilization, Convoy of Hope, etc.)?
5. The video that set up the talk spoke about ‚Äòlegacy.‚Äô What comes to mind when you think about your legacy? Are you dissatisfied with what will be your legacy? If not, what are you planning for your future?
6. Pastor Louie shared about the concept of exponential growth. What was the point of the Bank of America Plaza analogy? What did it make you think about in regards to investing your life in what matters most?
7. Why is the Gospel a story about generosity?
8. Does generosity feel like an obligation to you? If so, why? Does it feel like an inclination for you? If so, then when and why did the shift happen for you ‚Äì from obligation to inclination?

title: ABOVE + BEYOND - Kaab's Story
description:
CONTENT WARNING
This Jesus Story contains a description of an attempted suicide. Viewer discretion is advised.
If you are struggling with thoughts of taking your own life, please make the choice to stay and call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline @ 1-800-273-8255 or text 988.
‚Äî
Kaab invites us into his Above + Beyond story of how he went from not wanting to be alive and living in complete darkness, to falling on his knees and choosing Christ as his savior from his bedroom after watching a talk from a Passion conference. For the first time in 7 years, he didn‚Äôt want life to end. Through the grace of God, Passion is now weaved into the fabric of Kaab‚Äôs story.

Find out more about Above + Beyond by visiting https://passioncitychurch.com/above-and-beyond.

title: Living and Giving in the Above + Beyond - Louie Giglio + Allison Dukes
description:
In this talk leading up to Above + Beyond Sunday, Pastor Louie sits down with financial expert, Allison Dukes, to have a conversation about the biblical view and understanding of finances. God wants us to simultaneously live wisely with the resources He has entrusted to us all the while being open-handed and entirely trusting of the One who oversees and allocates every resource. 

Find out more about Above + Beyond by visiting https://passioncitychurch.com/above-and-beyond.
 
#faith #christian #sermon #passioncity #passioncityatlanta #atlanta #passioncitychurch #atlantachurch #christianity #Jesus #god

Passion City Church is a Jesus church with locations in Atlanta and Washington D.C.
‚Äî

Discussion Questions //

1. What previously came to mind about the topic of money and finances before this message?
2. Let‚Äôs answer the same question Allison Dukes answered. Pastor Louie asked, ‚ÄúHow was the Kingdom informed your view of the macro ‚Äòglobal‚Äô economy?‚Äù How would you answer this question?
3. Dukes talked about her note in her desk, ‚ÄúGive more than you get, leave more than you take.‚Äù How does this 1 Corinthians 4:7 mentality inform not just your finances but everything you do?
4. Go around the room and share your thinking in moments of generosity. Think specifically. What is it that you think about when you make a generous decision?
5. What are your Generosity Goals in life? In other words, what do you dream of being able to give? What organizations, people, or initiatives would you be honored to bless?
6. Allison Dukes spoke into the subject of the ‚Äúlove of money‚Äù and it would help to recall her wisdom in answering the following question (1 Tim. 6:10). What is the difference between ‚Äúdesiring to be rich,‚Äù like the Scriptures teach and desiring to be successful ‚Äì which is a biblically grounded and God-honoring desire (1 Tim. 6:9)?
7. Allison Dukes said that everything we have is meant to ‚Äúpass through.‚Äù What did she mean in saying this?
8. While you might not consider yourself ‚Äúrich,‚Äù the odds are that, if you watched this message, you are living as one of the wealthiest people on the planet. It takes a perspective-shift to grasp that reality. Read 1 Timothy 6:17-19 and talk about how this text reinforces what was shared in the conversation between Pastor Louie and Allison Dukes. Regardless of your financial situation, what is the instruction for followers of Jesus that comes from this text?
9. What thoughts and questions are you wrestling with in responding to the conversation you heard between Pastor Louie and Allison Dukes?

title: What It Means to Live as a Christian - Louie Giglio
description:
‚ÄúGod is still calling us to a process and a lifestyle of becoming everything He has created us to become, and by grace, He extends mercy to us every single day.‚Äù

Continuing in our current collection of talks, Believer, Pastor Louie stresses that being a Christian is more about who you are than what you do. To be Christian, we are called to be Christ-like, love God, extend grace, shine light, and champion those in need. When we can be mirrors, reflecting the glory of God, others can see Christ.

VERSES // John 1:14,3:16, Philippians 2:1-16, Galatians 2:20, 2 Corinthians 5:14, 1 Corinthians 1:23, Luke 10:27, Matthew 5:13-16

title: Are you just checking the "Christian" box? #chrstian #christianity #shorts
description:
"Instead of getting caught up in the exclusivity of the claims of Christ, why don't we just live out the beauty of Christ?"

Pastor Louie launches a new collection of talks, Believer, with a powerful message about what it means to be Christian. Believing in Christ is inclusive to everyone, though he identifies how our lives should identify Christ when we choose to follow Him. As followers of the Way, we entrust Jesus to lead us, and people who don't know Him will follow close behind.

VERSES // John 3:10-18, 2 Timothy 1:12, Acts 4:32,9:1-2,11:18-26

Pastor Louie Giglio brings a strong message into week two of God of the Impossible, highlighting the power of shifting our mindset and prayers toward possibility. Though we may not see a shift happening after we pray, we can believe that something will happen that reflects the power of our Father. We‚Äôre encouraged to ask for a miracle, believe that God is working, and surrender it into His hands.

title: You're in a divine symphony of God's redemption story. #shorts #god #jesus
description:
‚ÄúNo matter what your season, your story can end in restoration.‚Äù

Pastor Louie Giglio journeys through the book of Jeremiah, reminding us that God is a God of the impossible. There is loss in life on a broken planet, but even in the loss, God is working a redemption story. He encourages us to have ears to be attuned to the Word of God and to stand firm in our corner of faith, believing that God will do what He says He will do.

VERSES // Mark 10:23, Luke 1:37, Ephesians 3:20-21, Jeremiah 1:1-5,29:1,10-14,32:1-44

title: The Power of the Mind Fixed on the Cross of Christ - Louie Giglio
description:
Traveling through 1 Corinthians, Pastor Louie Giglio magnifies the meaning of having the cross as our true north. As our wounds, pain, loss, circumstances, opinions, beliefs, current state, and temporary pleasures shift, we are shown the power of the mind fixed on the finished work of the cross instead of the things of this world.

title: You can't fix the foundation by yourself. #shorts #jesus #god
description:
‚ÄúThere is no power apart from dependence.‚Äù

This Sunday we had the privilege of being joined by Dr. Crawford Loritts, as he reminds us of the importance of the Holy Spirit in our walk of faith. Diving into the book of Acts, we are taught that demonstrating the power of God and living a supernatural life is a commandment. As the spirit of God structurally changes us, we must model it ourselves by obeying His command and continually submitting to His control.

title: Look At What He's Done
description:
A voice whispers:
‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

we are marked by a lifetime of selfish choices, 
a legacy of harsh words,
and terrible thoughts 

‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

the constant jealousy
the envy of what others possess
the disregard for people in the pursuit of what we desire, 
what we insist we are entitled to‚Ä¶

The enemy whispers:
‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

hiding our addictions
telling lies to ourselves, to our spouses, (to our friends)
convincing the world that we are ‚Äúfine‚Äù while we are breaking into pieces 

‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

medicating our emptiness with screens and swipes
entertaining ourselves with the wicked, the pornographic, the disturbing  
feeding on luxury while forgetting the poor

Satan whispers:
‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

the betrayal of our own beliefs
from hype to hypocrisy 
building the walls of our own kingdom
loving darkness more than light

‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôve done!‚Äù

the bitterness
the gossip
the brooding
the prejudice

The Enemy is gloating:
Look at what you‚Äôve done! 

Look at all your shame. 
Look at all your guilt. 
Look at all your chains.
Look at what you‚Äôve done! 
You deserve wrath.
You deserve hell.
You deserve death. 
Look at what you‚Äôve done!

And really‚Ä¶ 

he‚Äôs right. 
That *is* what we‚Äôve done. 

But to every whisper, to every accusation‚Ä¶ 
we remind the enemy 
of Jesus. 
And we say,
‚ÄúLook at what He‚Äôs done.‚Äù 

He commanded the universe into being.
Light emerged from His voice. 
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done.

He scripted the totality of Time
and He wrote His glory into every line.
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done.

He stepped down from Heaven. Took on our flesh. 
He humbled Himself, becoming obedient to death. 
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done.

Forgiving our sins:
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done!

Dying in our place: 
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done!

He was dead. Buried. 
But then He rose from the grave. 
That‚Äôs what He‚Äôs done! 

Death. Defeated. 

Hell. Scorned. 

Debt. Paid. 

Veil. Torn.

No matter our past‚Ä¶ Jesus has overcome! 
The dead are alive! 

That‚Äôs 

what 

He‚Äôs 

done. 
‚Äî
Animation: Evan Pierce, Cole Jennerson, Zach Durden
Editing: Evan Pierce 
Text design: Chandler Saunders 
Written by: Jason Dyba

title: A Contemplation and Celebration of The Cross
description:
Just between the two of us‚Ä¶
It feels like there‚Äôs a divide. 
Like we‚Äôre breaking into pieces: 
(‚Ä¶our families, our churches, our society‚Ä¶)
Everybody picking their sides. 

‚Ä¶a burning world of disagreement 
between two or more opposing opinions. 
We are like children in the crossfire
between two warring dominions. 

Even inside our own heads
there‚Äôs a battle on every front
between doing what is right
and doing what we want. 

Between choosing what is holy
and succumbing to the flesh. 
We have all fallen short,
even at our best. 

There‚Äôs an ever-growing gap 
between our sin and God‚Äôs perfection. 
There‚Äôs an uncrossable canyon 
between our Hell-bent hearts and Heaven. 

In our destruction, we are dead ‚Äî 
on the wrong side of this great divide
desperately in need 
of a bridge between death and life. 

We would rightly give up hope;
to death, we would concede‚Ä¶
were it not for Jesus 
hanging there between 2 thieves. 

A cross between two crosses. 
The murder of an innocent man.
The quenching of God‚Äôs wrath
and the fulfillment of God‚Äôs plan. 

Between B.C. and A.D.
the centerpiece of Time; 
the eternal proof of God‚Äôs love for us 
written between the lines. 

This cross is our forgiveness, 
the full payment for what we‚Äôd done ‚Äî 
an exchange that had been brokered
between a Father and a Son. 

This cross can mend a splintered love. 
Every regret, it can atone. 
It is healing for the trauma 
in broken hearts of broken homes. 

This cross restores the soul. 
It brings peace to every sorrow. 
‚Ä¶turns the ashes of our past 
into the beauty of tomorrow. 

Between everything we‚Äôve lost 
Between every way we‚Äôve failed 
There is a King who chose to save us 
hanging there between 2 nails. 

For the Peters who deny him.
For the doubts of every Thomas. 
Between a Thursday and a Saturday,
God made Good on what He promised.

This cross is our redemption. 
The only healing for the nations. 
The blood of Jesus Christ 
is our one and sure salvation. 

We will live and not die. 
Our hope is found and not lost. 
‚Ä¶because between us and God 
there forever stands the cross. 

‚Äî
Created by the Passion Film Team
‚Äî
Musicbed SyncID:
MB01PA4IQNUU5Z1

title: What He's Done - Lyric Video
description:
The hinge of Christianity swings on one historical event: the resurrection of Jesus Christ. Without it, Paul said those of us who call ourselves ‚ÄúChristians‚Äù are to be the most pitied. God raises people from the dead. Resurrection is what He does. As we journey through Holy Week, take a few minutes to worship with us, and focus on the upcoming celebration of Christ's victory over death on Easter. 
‚Äî

My future is Heaven
I praise God for what He‚Äôs done
 
Sing! For the freedom He has won
Even death is dead and done
His life has overcome
 
Speak! Say the Name above all names
Over every broken place 
He is risen from the grave! 
 
Now on a throne of majesty
The Father‚Äôs will complete
He reigns in victory
 
Sing! Hallelujah to the King
He is worthy to receive
All the worship we can bring

title: At the Table with the King - Louie Giglio
description:

title: FIGHT FOR YOUR BROTHER
description:
Fight Night happened for the men of our city on Thursday, March 31st at our 515 Location. This was a night to hang out and gather with other guys in Atlanta as we talked about fighting FOR your brother.

Learn more about Fight Clubs at https://passioncitychurch.com/fightclub

‚Äî

"If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together."
-African Proverb

As men dedicated to living a life that not only starts well but finishes well, longevity can be a daunting or impossible task. Who could stand the test of time? How many men who stood for Godliness eventually succumb to the ways of living that Proverbs describes as clearly leading to demise? Research enough of these tragedies, or experience them yourself, and here is what you will find: lonely men, lacking Christ-centered community, are likely targets for deceit.

The truth is this, friendships can be challenging to establish and hard to maintain. They require vulnerability and a willingness, to be honest about your needs, desires, and worries. The level of intimacy necessary to spur one another on in faithful pursuit of a wisdom-filled life is even more so. That's why at Passion City Church we have Fight Clubs. 

A Fight Club, in simple terms, is an accountability group of 3-5 men‚Äîa place where friendship and encouragement is met with regular accountability that helps us stay focused on our goals and avoid the pitfalls that can easily sink our hopes. At its heart is not a Bible Study or discipleship group (although you will most likely talk about the Scripture often), but it is a group of men who share a similar season of life and meet consistently to help each other win the fight.

‚Äî

#fightclub #men #brotherhood #passioncity #passioncitychurch #christian

title: Jesus is Coming Soon* - Louie Giglio
description:
*[SOON] in the biblical sense, is a relative term when used in relation to the eternal nature of the
ALMIGHTY, who exists outside time and space, yet concurrently operates within the confines of finite human history as 'I AM; God the same yesterday, today, forever. Thus, the use of the term "soon' as understood by the eternal mind may be interpreted to mean promptly (as in right now) or to mean a future time, say within the next 100-1000 years, the later of which, in God time, is the equivalent of one human day, therefore "soon."

title: ABOVE + BEYOND: Here & Everywhere
description:
The Wind is blowing. 
It blew in 2017, stirring a church to give and start a new community in Washington, D.C. Because of this community, Anna was able to weather seven months of unemployment this year. 
It blew in 2019, leading Astrid to pray for a girl in her Community Group to start following Jesus. This year, she got to baptize Sophie and Grace, who continue shining Jesus‚Äô light to those on their campus. 
The love of Jesus knows no boundary, and calls us to go above and beyond normal, into the wind, to every here and to everywhere.
---
When you give to Above and Beyond, you play an active role in bringing Scripture to five people groups who have never seen a word of it in their own language. You make it possible to launch a new campus in South Atlanta. You contribute to local ministries, outreaches, and schools in both Atlanta and D.C. 
When you give to Above and Beyond, you take your first step into the same Wind blowing here and everywhere.

title: The Fear of God
description:
Dear friends, I urge you, as foreigners and exiles, to abstain from sinful desires, which wage war against your soul. Live such good lives among the pagans that, though they accuse you of doing wrong, they may see your good deeds and glorify God on the day he visits us. Submit yourselves for the Lord‚Äôs sake to every human authority: whether to the emperor, as the supreme authority, or to governors, who are sent by him to punish those who do wrong and to commend those who do right. For it is God‚Äôs will that by doing good you should silence the ignorant talk of foolish people. Live as free people, but do not use your freedom as a cover-up for evil; live as God‚Äôs slaves. Show proper respect to everyone, love the family of believers, fear God, honor the emperor.
1 Peter 2: 11-17
‚Äî
This week, Pastor Louie Giglio walks with us through one of the important ideas in scripture: all of us who call ourselves Christians are on display, living among the lost, and most of us are the only representation of the Gospel that the people in our worlds will ever see. So how are we living that out? What are we actually putting on display with our lives?

title: A Chip Off the Old Block - Louie Giglio
description:
Here's what is true; we are all going to go in the fire at one point or another. We will face seemingly insurmountable obstacles and immovable mountains. Life will not go according to our plans, and we will find ourselves in a furnace, wondering how long we can stand the fire. That is until we remember that we are not standing on the flames themselves. We are fixed upon that sure foundation, the cornerstone of Jesus. He is our rock, our living stone. 

This is good news because standing on a living rock means we are never alone. He is in the fire with us. And while Jesus is with us in the trials, guess who is watching Him work‚Ä¶ the whole world.

title: ABOVE + BEYOND
description:

Through it all, every heart that has come alive, every need fulfilled, every challenge overcome, Jesus has been weaving together a family of believers built on the goodness of His Gospel and the dedication of His people. The stunning truth is that this story is but a glimpse of God's love for his people, and so we celebrate. This is not just the end of a three-year arc; it is the beginning of the next chapter of our House. Written by the God of immeasurably more, through the generosity of His children, this is ABOVE + BEYOND.

description:
‚ÄúHumility is birthed at the foot of the cross."

In the second week of our series ANCHOR, Pastor Ben Stuart brings a timely and important message about the radical grace of God. We are not only reconciled with God through the cross; the cross also restore relationships with each other. The grace of God is so radical that it makes enemies not just into friends but into family.

title: Life is Hard ‚Äî God is Good - Louie Giglio
description:
Almost nothing is guaranteed, except for two things:

Life is Hard. God is Good.

That‚Äôs it; those are the two guarantees we‚Äôre walking away with today. The first one, life is hard, no one ever really had to teach us. The second one is a whole different story. 

God is good‚Ä¶ all the time.

So what happens when that truth faces off against real life? What happens when we are confronted with the truth that the story of Jesus-followers is a story of hardship? How do we reconcile the mountain of victory we‚Äôre standing on with the hardship the story of our spiritual lineage holds?

We embrace it and we look at the life of Paul.
‚Äî

David was anointed by God as a teenager, told he would be king in time. He played the harp for the king, killed the giant Goliath, became the head of the military and married the king‚Äôs daughter. David was the most famous person in the whole kingdom and beloved by everyone around him.
 
Everyone except the king. 

Join Pastor Ben Stuart as he breaks down how each of us can learn from the life of David how we can handle hard times in a way that leads us to a heroic life.

title: I'm Not Okay But Jesus Is - Louie Giglio
description:

title: It's Okay to Freak Out - Louie Giglio
description:
Even the heroes of our faith, men and women who walked with God for decades, had moments where they felt like they couldn‚Äôt go on.

Hear my cry, O God;
    listen to my prayer.
From the ends of the earth I call to you,
    I call as my heart grows faint;
    lead me to the rock that is higher than I.
For you have been my refuge,
    a strong tower against the foe.
Psalm 61:1-3

David knew what it felt like to experience moments of desperation. If the man who conquered Goliath (with the help of God) as a small child found his heart growing faint at times, maybe we can say to ourselves: 

It's okay to freak out.

title: How Will We Make It? - Ben Stuart
description:
These days are hard. They aren‚Äôt what we planned, and there‚Äôs no end in sight. So how are we supposed to not only live through these days but to live well in the midst of them?

The answer can be found in the book of Hebrews.

But recall the former days when, after you were enlightened, you endured a hard struggle with sufferings, (you came out of the blocks strong!) sometimes being publicly exposed to reproach and affliction, and sometimes being partners with those so treated. For you had compassion on those in prison, and you joyfully accepted the plundering of your property, since you knew that you yourselves had a better possession and an abiding one. Therefore do not throw away your confidence, which has a great reward. For you have need of endurance, so that when you have done the will of God you may receive what is promised. 
Hebrews 10:32-36

Endurance, we need endurance.

Here‚Äôs the good news. You can have it. 

So how do we gain the endurance we are going to need in order not only to endure the days ahead but to excel in them?

Overwhelming? Yes. 
Original? No. 

It's the very same question that has bounced around the minds of believers and skeptics for thousands of years.

title: Why Christianity is Not a Crutch - Louie Giglio
description:
"We have never seen anything like this." 

How many times have you heard that this week? We're living in unprecedented times to be sure, but are we on our own? Whenever faced with times of uncertainty, doesn't it feel like we hear people taking one of two stances? Either we believe that our hope and confidence is in a sovereign God who always has and will always have a plan for our good and His Glory, or we can believe that in one way or another faith in God is simply a crutch to lean on when we aren't strong enough to face what is right in front of us. 

But Christianity is not a crutch. 
‚Äî
This week Pastor Louie Giglio brings a message that is timely to the days we are living in. Teaching out of Mark 2:1-12 Pastor Louie reminds us of a few critical things:

1. Our faith can move the heart of God and impact the eternal destiny of someone around us.
2. The paralyzed man's problem was bigger than he thought.
3. Jesus didn't offer a crutch. He healed him. 
‚Äî
